017package com.github.tommyettinger.colorful.pure.rgb;
018
019import com.github.tommyettinger.colorful.pure.FloatColors;
020import com.github.tommyettinger.digital.BitConversion;
021
022import java.util.Random;
023
024/**
025 * Contains code for manipulating colors as {@code int} and packed {@code float} values in the RGB color space.
026 * All of these colors have an alpha channel as well as red, green, and blue; the package name isn't
027 * "rgba" because "ycwcm" and "ipt" don't mention alpha either and they also have that channel. RGB is the standard mode
028 * for colors in libGDX, and conversions to and from RGB are in the ColorTools classes for each other color space (like
029 * {@link com.github.tommyettinger.colorful.pure.ipt.ColorTools#fromRGBA(float, float, float, float)} and
030 * {@link com.github.tommyettinger.colorful.pure.ycwcm.ColorTools#toRGBA(float)}).
031 */
032public class ColorTools {
033        /**
034         * Gets a packed float representation of a color given as 4 float components, here, R (red), G (green), B (blue),
035         * and A (alpha or opacity). All channels range
036         * from 0.0 to 1.0, inclusive. Alpha is the multiplicative opacity of the color.
037         * <br>
038         * This method bit-masks the resulting color's byte values, so any values can technically be given to this as red,
039         * green, and blue, but they will only be reversible from the returned float color to the original R, G, and B
040         * values if the original values were in the range that {@link #red(float)}, {@link #green(float)}, and
041         * {@link #blue(float)} return.
042         *
043         * @param red       0f to 1f, red channel
044         * @param green     0f to 1f, green channel
045         * @param blue      0f to 1f, blue channel
046         * @param alpha     0f to 1f, 0f makes the color transparent and 1f makes it opaque
047         * @return a float encoding a color with the given properties
048         */
049        public static float rgb(float red, float green, float blue, float alpha) {
050                return BitConversion.intBitsToFloat(((int) (alpha * 255) << 24 & 0xFE000000) | ((int) (blue * 255) << 16 & 0xFF0000)
051                                | ((int) (green * 255) << 8 & 0xFF00) | ((int) (red * 255) & 0xFF));
052        }
053
054        /**
055         * Converts a packed float color in the format produced by {@link #rgb(float, float, float, float)} to an
056         * RGBA8888 int. This format of int can be used with Pixmap and in some other places in libGDX.
057         * @param packed a packed float color, as produced by {@link #rgb(float, float, float, float)}
058         * @return an RGBA8888 int color
059         */
060        public static int toRGBA8888(final float packed) {
061                final int rev = Integer.reverseBytes(BitConversion.floatToRawIntBits(packed));
062                return rev | (rev >>> 7 & 1);
063        }
064
065        /**
066         * Takes a color encoded as an RGBA8888 int and converts to a packed float in the RGB format this uses.
067         * @param rgba an int with the channels (in order) red, green, blue, alpha; should have 8 bits per channel
068         * @return a packed float as RGB, which this class can use
069         */
070        public static float fromRGBA8888(final int rgba) {
071                return BitConversion.intBitsToFloat(Integer.reverseBytes(rgba) & 0xFEFFFFFF);
072        }
073
074        /**
075         * Takes RGBA components from 0.0 to 1.0 each and converts to a packed float in the RGBA format this uses.
076         * @param r red, from 0.0 to 1.0 (both inclusive)
077         * @param g green, from 0.0 to 1.0 (both inclusive)
078         * @param b blue, from 0.0 to 1.0 (both inclusive)
079         * @param a alpha, from 0.0 to 1.0 (both inclusive)
080         * @return a packed float as RGBA, which this class can use
081         */
082        public static float fromRGBA(final float r, final float g, final float b, final float a) {
083                return BitConversion.intBitsToFloat(
084                                          Math.min(Math.max((int)(r * 255.0f + 0.500f), 0), 255)
085                                                | Math.min(Math.max((int)(g * 255.0f + 0.500f), 0), 255) << 8
086                                                | Math.min(Math.max((int)(b * 255.0f + 0.500f), 0), 255) << 16
087                                                | ((int)(a * 255f) << 24 & 0xFE000000));
088        }
089
090        /**
091         * Gets the red channel value of the given encoded color, as an int ranging from 0 to 255, inclusive.
092         * @param encoded a color as a packed float that can be obtained by {@link #rgb(float, float, float, float)}
093         * @return an int from 0 to 255, inclusive, representing the red channel value of the given encoded color
094         */
095        public static int redInt(final float encoded) {
096                final int decoded = BitConversion.floatToRawIntBits(encoded);
097                return (decoded & 0xff);
098        }
099
100        /**
101         * Gets the green channel value of the given encoded color, as an int ranging from 0 to 255, inclusive.
102         * @param encoded a color as a packed float that can be obtained by {@link #rgb(float, float, float, float)}
103         * @return an int from 0 to 255, inclusive, representing the green channel value of the given encoded color
104         */
105        public static int greenInt(final float encoded) {
106                final int decoded = BitConversion.floatToRawIntBits(encoded);
107                return (decoded >>> 8 & 0xff);
108        }
109
110        /**
111         * Gets the blue channel value of the given encoded color, as an int ranging from 0 to 255, inclusive.
112         * @param encoded a color as a packed float that can be obtained by {@link #rgb(float, float, float, float)}
113         * @return an int from 0 to 255, inclusive, representing the blue channel value of the given encoded color
114         */
115        public static int blueInt(final float encoded) {
116                final int decoded = BitConversion.floatToRawIntBits(encoded);
117                return  (decoded >>> 16 & 0xff);
118        }
119
120        /**
121         * Gets the alpha channel value of the given encoded color, as an even int ranging from 0 to 254, inclusive. Because
122         * of how alpha is stored in libGDX, no odd-number values are possible for alpha.
123         * @param encoded a color as a packed float that can be obtained by {@link #rgb(float, float, float, float)}
124         * @return an even int from 0 to 254, inclusive, representing the alpha channel value of the given encoded color
125         */
126        public static int alphaInt(final float encoded) {
127                return (BitConversion.floatToRawIntBits(encoded) & 0xfe000000) >>> 24;
128        }
129
130        /**
131         * Gets the red channel value of the given encoded color, as a float from 0.0f to 1.0f, inclusive.
132         * @param encoded a color as a packed float that can be obtained by {@link #rgb(float, float, float, float)}
133         * @return a float from 0.0f to 1.0f, inclusive, representing the red channel value of the given encoded color
134         */
135        public static float red(final float encoded) {
136                final int decoded = BitConversion.floatToRawIntBits(encoded);
137                return  (decoded & 0xff) / 255f;
138        }
139
140        /**
141         * Gets the green channel value of the given encoded color, as a float from 0.0f to 1.0f, inclusive.
142         * @param encoded a color as a packed float that can be obtained by {@link #rgb(float, float, float, float)}
143         * @return a float from 0.0f to 1.0f, inclusive, representing the green channel value of the given encoded color
144         */
145        public static float green(final float encoded) {
146                final int decoded = BitConversion.floatToRawIntBits(encoded);
147                return  (decoded >>> 8 & 0xff) / 255f;
148        }
149
150        /**
151         * Gets the blue channel value of the given encoded color, as a float from 0.0f to 1.0f, inclusive.
152         * @param encoded a color as a packed float that can be obtained by {@link #rgb(float, float, float, float)}
153         * @return a float from 0.0f to 1.0f, inclusive, representing the blue channel value of the given encoded color
154         */
155        public static float blue(final float encoded) {
156                final int decoded = BitConversion.floatToRawIntBits(encoded);
157                return  (decoded >>> 16 & 0xff) / 255f;
158        }
159
160        /**
161         * Gets the alpha channel value of the given encoded color, as a float from 0.0f to 1.0f, inclusive.
162         * @param encoded a color as a packed float that can be obtained by {@link #rgb(float, float, float, float)}
163         * @return a float from 0.0f to 1.0f, inclusive, representing the alpha channel value of the given encoded color
164         */
165        public static float alpha(final float encoded) {
166                return ((BitConversion.floatToRawIntBits(encoded) & 0xfe000000) >>> 24) * 0x1.020408p-8f;
167        }
168
169        /**
170         * Gets a color as an RGBA packed float given floats representing hue, saturation, lightness, and opacity.
171         * All parameters should normally be between 0 and 1 inclusive, though any hue is tolerated (precision loss may
172         * affect the color if the hue is too large). A hue of 0 is red, progressively higher hue values go to orange,
173         * yellow, green, blue, and purple before wrapping around to red as it approaches 1. A saturation of 0 is grayscale,
174         * a saturation of 1 is brightly colored, and values close to 1 will usually appear more distinct than values close
175         * to 0, especially if the hue is different. A lightness of 0.001f or less is always black (also using a shortcut if
176         * this is the case, respecting opacity), while a lightness of 1f is white. Very bright colors are mostly in a band
177         * of high-saturation where lightness is 0.5f.
178         *
179         * @param hue        0f to 1f, color wheel position
180         * @param saturation 0f to 1f, 0f is grayscale and 1f is brightly colored
181         * @param lightness  0f to 1f, 0f is black and 1f is white
182         * @param opacity    0f to 1f, 0f is fully transparent and 1f is opaque
183         * @return a float encoding a color with the given properties
184         */
185        public static float floatGetHSL(float hue, float saturation, float lightness, float opacity) {
186                if (lightness <= 0.001f) {
187                        return BitConversion.intBitsToFloat((((int) (opacity * 255f) << 24) & 0xFE000000));
188                } else if (lightness >= 0.999f) {
189                        return BitConversion.intBitsToFloat((((int) (opacity * 255f) << 24) & 0xFE000000) | 0x00FFFFFF);
190                } else {
191                        return FloatColors.hsl2rgb(hue, saturation, lightness, opacity);
192                }
193        }
194
195        /**
196         * Gets the saturation of the given encoded color, as a float ranging from 0.0f to 1.0f, inclusive.
197         * @param encoded a color as a packed float that can be obtained by {@link #rgb(float, float, float, float)}
198         * @return the saturation of the color from 0.0 (a grayscale color; inclusive) to 1.0 (a bright color, inclusive)
199         */
200        public static float saturation(final float encoded) {
201                final int decoded = BitConversion.floatToRawIntBits(encoded);
202                final float r = (decoded & 0xff) / 255f;
203                final float g = (decoded >>> 8 & 0xff) / 255f;
204                final float b = (decoded >>> 16 & 0xff) / 255f;
205                float x, y, w;
206                if(g < b) {
207                        x = b;
208                        y = g;
209                }
210                else {
211                        x = g;
212                        y = b;
213                }
214                if(r < x) {
215                        w = r;
216                }
217                else {
218                        w = x;
219                        x = r;
220                }
221                return x - Math.min(w, y);
222//              float d = x - Math.min(w, y);
223//              float li = x * (1f - 0.5f * d / (x + 1e-10f));
224//              return (x - li); // (Math.min(li, 1f - li) + 1e-10f);
225        }
226
227        public static float lightness(final float encoded) {
228                final int decoded = BitConversion.floatToRawIntBits(encoded);
229                final float r = (decoded & 0xff) / 255f;
230                final float g = (decoded >>> 8 & 0xff) / 255f;
231                final float b = (decoded >>> 16 & 0xff) / 255f;
232                float x, y, w;
233                if(g < b) {
234                        x = b;
235                        y = g;
236                }
237                else {
238                        x = g;
239                        y = b;
240                }
241                if(r < x) {
242                        w = r;
243                }
244                else {
245                        w = x;
246                        x = r;
247                }
248                float d = x - Math.min(w, y);
249                return x * (1f - 0.5f * d / (x + 1e-10f));
250        }
251
252        /**
253         * Gets the hue of the given encoded color, as a float from 0f (inclusive, red and approaching orange if increased)
254         * to 1f (exclusive, red and approaching purple if decreased).
255         * @param encoded a color as a packed float that can be obtained by {@link #rgb(float, float, float, float)}
256         * @return The hue of the color from 0.0 (red, inclusive) towards orange, then yellow, and
257         * eventually to purple before looping back to almost the same red (1.0, exclusive)
258         */
259        public static float hue(final float encoded) {
260                final int decoded = BitConversion.floatToRawIntBits(encoded);
261                final float r = (decoded & 0xff) / 255f;
262                final float g = (decoded >>> 8 & 0xff) / 255f;
263                final float b = (decoded >>> 16 & 0xff) / 255f;
264                float x, y, z, w;
265                if(g < b) {
266                        x = b;
267                        y = g;
268                        z = -1f;
269                        w = 2f / 3f;
270                }
271                else {
272                        x = g;
273                        y = b;
274                        z = 0f;
275                        w = -1f / 3f;
276                }
277                if(r < x) {
278                        z = w;
279                        w = r;
280                }
281                else {
282                        w = x;
283                        x = r;
284                }
285                float d = x - Math.min(w, y);
286                return Math.abs(z + (w - y) / (6f * d + 1e-10f));
287        }
288
289        /**
290         * Gets a variation on the packed float color basis as another packed float that has its hue, saturation, lightness,
291         * and opacity adjusted by the specified amounts. Note that this edits the color in HSL space, not RGB! Takes
292         * floats representing the amounts of change to apply to hue, saturation, lightness, and opacity; these can be
293         * between -1f and 1f. Returns a float that can be used as a packed or encoded color. The float is
294         * likely to be different than the result of {@link #rgb(float, float, float, float)} unless hue, saturation,
295         * lightness, and opacity are all 0. This won't allocate any objects.
296         * <br>
297         * The parameters this takes all specify additive changes for a color component, clamping the final values so they
298         * can't go above 1 or below 0, with an exception for hue, which can rotate around if lower or higher hues would be
299         * used. As an example, if you give this 0.4f for saturation, and the current color has saturation 0.7f, then the
300         * resulting color will have 1f for saturation. If you gave this -0.1f for saturation and the current color again
301         * has saturation 0.7f, then resulting color will have 0.6f for saturation.
302         *
303         * @param basis      a packed float color that will be used as the starting point to make the next color
304         * @param hue        -1f to 1f, the hue change that can be applied to the new float color (not clamped, wraps)
305         * @param saturation -1f to 1f, the saturation change that can be applied to the new float color
306         * @param light      -1f to 1f, the light/brightness change that can be applied to the new float color
307         * @param opacity    -1f to 1f, the opacity/alpha change that can be applied to the new float color
308         * @return a float encoding a variation of basis with the given changes
309         */
310        public static float toEditedFloat(float basis, float hue, float saturation, float light, float opacity) {
311                final int decoded = BitConversion.floatToRawIntBits(basis);
312                opacity = Math.min(Math.max(opacity + (decoded >>> 25) * (1f / 127f), 0f), 1f);
313                final float r = (decoded & 0xff) / 255f;
314                final float g = (decoded >>> 8 & 0xff) / 255f;
315                final float b = (decoded >>> 16 & 0xff) / 255f;
316                float x, y, z, w;
317                if(g < b) {
318                        x = b;
319                        y = g;
320                        z = -1f;
321                        w = 2f / 3f;
322                }
323                else {
324                        x = g;
325                        y = b;
326                        z = 0f;
327                        w = -1f / 3f;
328                }
329                if(r < x) {
330                        z = w;
331                        w = r;
332                }
333                else {
334                        w = x;
335                        x = r;
336                }
337                final float d = x - Math.min(w, y);
338                final float lum = x * (1f - 0.5f * d / (x + 1e-10f));
339                hue += Math.abs(z + (w - y) / (6f * d + 1e-10f)) + 1f;
340                saturation += (x - lum) / (Math.min(lum, 1f - lum) + 1e-10f);
341                return FloatColors.hsl2rgb(hue - (int)hue, Math.min(Math.max(saturation, 0f), 1f), Math.min(Math.max(lum + light, 0f), 1f), opacity);
342        }
343
344        /**
345         * Interpolates from the packed float color start towards white by change. While change should be between 0f (return
346         * start as-is) and 1f (return white), start should be a packed color, as from
347         * {@link #rgb(float, float, float, float)}. This is a good way to reduce allocations of temporary Colors, and
348         * is a little more efficient and clear than using {@link FloatColors#lerpFloatColors(float, float, float)} to lerp towards
349         * white. Unlike {@link FloatColors#lerpFloatColors(float, float, float)}, this keeps the alpha and both chroma of start as-is.
350         * @see #darken(float, float) the counterpart method that darkens a float color
351         * @param start the starting color as a packed float
352         * @param change how much to go from start toward white, as a float between 0 and 1; higher means closer to white
353         * @return a packed float that represents a color between start and white
354         */
355        public static float lighten(final float start, final float change) {
356                final int s = BitConversion.floatToRawIntBits(start), r = s & 0xFF, g = s >>> 8 & 0xFF, b = s >>> 16 & 0xFF,
357                                a = s & 0xFE000000;
358                return BitConversion.intBitsToFloat(
359                                ((int) (r + (0xFF - r) * change) & 0xFF) |
360                                ((int) (g + (0xFF - g) * change) & 0xFF) << 8 |
361                                ((int) (b + (0xFF - b) * change) & 0xFF) << 16 |
362                                a);
363        }
364
365        /**
366         * Interpolates from the packed float color start towards black by change. While change should be between 0f (return
367         * start as-is) and 1f (return black), start should be a packed color, as from
368         * {@link #rgb(float, float, float, float)}. This is a good way to reduce allocations of temporary Colors, and
369         * is a little more efficient and clear than using {@link FloatColors#lerpFloatColors(float, float, float)} to lerp towards
370         * black. Unlike {@link FloatColors#lerpFloatColors(float, float, float)}, this keeps the alpha and both chroma of start as-is.
371         * @see #lighten(float, float) the counterpart method that lightens a float color
372         * @param start the starting color as a packed float
373         * @param change how much to go from start toward black, as a float between 0 and 1; higher means closer to black
374         * @return a packed float that represents a color between start and black
375         */
376        public static float darken(final float start, final float change) {
377                final int s = BitConversion.floatToRawIntBits(start), r = s & 0xFF, g = s >>> 8 & 0xFF, b = s >>> 16 & 0xFF,
378                                a = s & 0xFE000000;
379                return BitConversion.intBitsToFloat(
380                                ((int) (r * (1f - change)) & 0xFF) |
381                                ((int) (g * (1f - change)) & 0xFF) << 8 |
382                                ((int) (b * (1f - change)) & 0xFF) << 16 |
383                                a);
384        }
385
386        /**
387         * Brings the chromatic components of {@code start} closer to grayscale by {@code change} (desaturating them). While
388         * change should be between 0f (return start as-is) and 1f (return fully gray), start should be a packed color, as
389         * from {@link #rgb(float, float, float, float)}. This leaves alpha alone, unlike
390         * {@link #lessenChange(float, float)}, which usually changes Y.
391         * <br>
392         * <a href="http://www.graficaobscura.com/matrix/index.html">The algorithm used is from here</a>.
393         * @see #enrich(float, float) the counterpart method that makes a float color more saturated
394         * @param start the starting color as a packed float
395         * @param change how much to change start to a desaturated color, as a float between 0 and 1; higher means a less saturated result
396         * @return a packed float that represents a color between start and a desaturated color
397         */
398        public static float dullen(final float start, final float change) {
399                final float rc = 0.32627f, gc = 0.3678f, bc = 0.30593001f;
400                final int s = BitConversion.floatToRawIntBits(start), r = s & 0xFF, g = s >>> 8 & 0xFF, b = s >>> 16 & 0xFF,
401                                a = s & 0xFE000000;
402                final float ch = 1f - change, rw = change * rc, gw = change * gc, bw = change * bc;
403                return BitConversion.intBitsToFloat(
404                                (int) Math.min(Math.max(r * (rw+ch) + g * rw + b * rw, 0), 255) |
405                                                (int) Math.min(Math.max(r * gw + g * (gw+ch) + b * gw, 0), 255) << 8 |
406                                                (int) Math.min(Math.max(r * bw + g * bw + b * (bw+ch), 0), 255) << 16 |
407                                                a);
408        }
409
410        /**
411         * Pushes the chromatic components of {@code start} away from grayscale by change (saturating them). While change
412         * should be between 0f (return start as-is) and 1f (return maximally saturated), start should be a packed color, as
413         * from {@link #rgb(float, float, float, float)}.
414         * <br>
415         * <a href="http://www.graficaobscura.com/matrix/index.html">The algorithm used is from here</a>.
416         * @see #dullen(float, float) the counterpart method that makes a float color less saturated
417         * @param start the starting color as a packed float
418         * @param change how much to change start to a saturated color, as a float between 0 and 1; higher means a more saturated result
419         * @return a packed float that represents a color between start and a saturated color
420         */
421        public static float enrich(final float start, final float change) {
422                final float rc = 0.32627f, gc = 0.3678f, bc = 0.30593001f;
423                final int s = BitConversion.floatToRawIntBits(start), r = s & 0xFF, g = s >>> 8 & 0xFF, b = s >>> 16 & 0xFF,
424                                a = s & 0xFE000000;
425                final float ch = 1f + change, rw = (-change) * rc, gw = (-change) * gc, bw = (-change) * bc;
426                return BitConversion.intBitsToFloat(
427                                (int) Math.min(Math.max(r * (rw+ch) + g * rw + b * rw, 0), 255) |
428                                                (int) Math.min(Math.max(r * gw + g * (gw+ch) + b * gw, 0), 255) << 8 |
429                                                (int) Math.min(Math.max(r * bw + g * bw + b * (bw+ch), 0), 255) << 16 |
430                                                a);
431        }
432
433        /**
434         * Interpolates from the packed float color start to increase its red channel by change.
435         * While change must be between 0f (return start as-is) and 1f (return maximum red), start should be a packed
436         * color, as from {@link #rgb(float, float, float, float)}. This is a good way to reduce allocations of temporary
437         * Colors, and is a little more efficient and clear than using
438         * {@link FloatColors#lerpFloatColors(float, float, float)} to lerp towards a more-red color. Unlike
439         * {@link FloatColors#lerpFloatColors(float, float, float)}, this keeps the other channels of start as-is.
440         * @see #lowerB(float, float) the counterpart method that makes a float color less red
441         * @param start the starting color as a packed float
442         * @param change how much to change start to a more-red color, as a float between 0 and 1; higher means more red
443         * @return a packed float that represents a color between start and a more red color
444         */
445        public static float raiseR(final float start, final float change) {
446                final int s = BitConversion.floatToRawIntBits(start), t = s & 0xFF, other = s & 0xFEFFFF00;
447                return BitConversion.intBitsToFloat(((int) (t + (0xFF - t) * change) & 0xFF) | other);
448        }
449
450        /**
451         * Interpolates from the packed float color start to decrease its red channel by change.
452         * While change must be between 0f (return start as-is) and 1f (return minimum red), start should be a packed
453         * color, as from {@link #rgb(float, float, float, float)}. This is a good way to reduce allocations of temporary
454         * Colors, and is a little more efficient and clear than using
455         * {@link FloatColors#lerpFloatColors(float, float, float)} to lerp towards a less-red color. Unlike
456         * {@link FloatColors#lerpFloatColors(float, float, float)}, this keeps the other channels of start as-is.
457         * @see #raiseB(float, float) the counterpart method that makes a float color more red
458         * @param start the starting color as a packed float
459         * @param change how much to change start to a less-red color, as a float between 0 and 1; higher means less red
460         * @return a packed float that represents a color between start and a less red color
461         */
462        public static float lowerR(final float start, final float change) {
463                final int s = BitConversion.floatToRawIntBits(start), t = s & 0xFF, other = s & 0xFEFFFF00;
464                return BitConversion.intBitsToFloat(((int) (t * (1f - change)) & 0xFF) | other);
465        }
466
467        /**
468         * Interpolates from the packed float color start to increase its green channel by change.
469         * While change must be between 0f (return start as-is) and 1f (return maximum green), start should be a packed
470         * color, as from {@link #rgb(float, float, float, float)}. This is a good way to reduce allocations of temporary
471         * Colors, and is a little more efficient and clear than using
472         * {@link FloatColors#lerpFloatColors(float, float, float)} to lerp towards a more-green color. Unlike
473         * {@link FloatColors#lerpFloatColors(float, float, float)}, this keeps the other channels of start as-is.
474         * @see #lowerB(float, float) the counterpart method that makes a float color less green
475         * @param start the starting color as a packed float
476         * @param change how much to change start to a more-green color, as a float between 0 and 1; higher means more green
477         * @return a packed float that represents a color between start and a more green color
478         */
479        public static float raiseG(final float start, final float change) {
480                final int s = BitConversion.floatToRawIntBits(start), t = s >>> 8 & 0xFF, other = s & 0xFEFF00FF;
481                return BitConversion.intBitsToFloat(((int) (t + (0xFF - t) * change) << 8 & 0xFF00) | other);
482        }
483
484        /**
485         * Interpolates from the packed float color start to decrease its green channel by change.
486         * While change must be between 0f (return start as-is) and 1f (return minimum green), start should be a packed
487         * color, as from {@link #rgb(float, float, float, float)}. This is a good way to reduce allocations of temporary
488         * Colors, and is a little more efficient and clear than using
489         * {@link FloatColors#lerpFloatColors(float, float, float)} to lerp towards a less-green color. Unlike
490         * {@link FloatColors#lerpFloatColors(float, float, float)}, this keeps the other channels of start as-is.
491         * @see #raiseB(float, float) the counterpart method that makes a float color more green
492         * @param start the starting color as a packed float
493         * @param change how much to change start to a less-green color, as a float between 0 and 1; higher means less green
494         * @return a packed float that represents a color between start and a less green color
495         */
496        public static float lowerG(final float start, final float change) {
497                final int s = BitConversion.floatToRawIntBits(start), t = s >>> 8 & 0xFF, other = s & 0xFEFF00FF;
498                return BitConversion.intBitsToFloat(((int) (t * (1f - change)) & 0xFF) << 8 | other);
499        }
500
501        /**
502         * Interpolates from the packed float color start to increase its blue channel by change.
503         * While change must be between 0f (return start as-is) and 1f (return maximum blue), start should be a packed
504         * color, as from {@link #rgb(float, float, float, float)}. This is a good way to reduce allocations of temporary
505         * Colors, and is a little more efficient and clear than using
506         * {@link FloatColors#lerpFloatColors(float, float, float)} to lerp towards a more-blue color. Unlike
507         * {@link FloatColors#lerpFloatColors(float, float, float)}, this keeps the other channels of start as-is.
508         * @see #lowerB(float, float) the counterpart method that makes a float color less blue
509         * @param start the starting color as a packed float
510         * @param change how much to change start to a more-blue color, as a float between 0 and 1; higher means more blue
511         * @return a packed float that represents a color between start and a more blue color
512         */
513        public static float raiseB(final float start, final float change) {
514                final int s = BitConversion.floatToRawIntBits(start), t = s >>> 16 & 0xFF, other = s & 0xFE00FFFF;
515                return BitConversion.intBitsToFloat(((int) (t + (0xFF - t) * change) << 16 & 0xFF0000) | other);
516        }
517
518        /**
519         * Interpolates from the packed float color start to decrease its blue channel by change.
520         * While change must be between 0f (return start as-is) and 1f (return minimum blue), start should be a packed
521         * color, as from {@link #rgb(float, float, float, float)}. This is a good way to reduce allocations of temporary
522         * Colors, and is a little more efficient and clear than using
523         * {@link FloatColors#lerpFloatColors(float, float, float)} to lerp towards a less-blue color. Unlike
524         * {@link FloatColors#lerpFloatColors(float, float, float)}, this keeps the other channels of start as-is.
525         * @see #raiseB(float, float) the counterpart method that makes a float color more blue
526         * @param start the starting color as a packed float
527         * @param change how much to change start to a less-blue color, as a float between 0 and 1; higher means less blue
528         * @return a packed float that represents a color between start and a less blue color
529         */
530        public static float lowerB(final float start, final float change) {
531                final int s = BitConversion.floatToRawIntBits(start), t = s >>> 16 & 0xFF, other = s & 0xFE00FFFF;
532                return BitConversion.intBitsToFloat(((int) (t * (1f - change)) & 0xFF) << 16 | other);
533        }
534
535        /**
536         * Interpolates from the packed float color start towards that color made opaque by change. While change should be
537         * between 0f (return start as-is) and 1f (return start with full alpha), start should be a packed color, as from
538         * {@link #rgb(float, float, float, float)}. This is a good way to reduce allocations of temporary Colors, and
539         * is a little more efficient and clear than using {@link FloatColors#lerpFloatColors(float, float, float)} to lerp towards
540         * transparent. This won't change the intensity, protan, or tritan of the color.
541         * @see #fade(float, float) the counterpart method that makes a float color more translucent
542         * @param start the starting color as a packed float
543         * @param change how much to go from start toward opaque, as a float between 0 and 1; higher means closer to opaque
544         * @return a packed float that represents a color between start and its opaque version
545         */
546        public static float blot(final float start, final float change) {
547                final int s = BitConversion.floatToRawIntBits(start), opacity = s >>> 24 & 0xFE, other = s & 0x00FFFFFF;
548                return BitConversion.intBitsToFloat(((int) (opacity + (0xFE - opacity) * change) & 0xFE) << 24 | other);
549        }
550
551        /**
552         * Interpolates from the packed float color start towards transparent by change. While change should be between 0
553         * (return start as-is) and 1f (return the color with 0 alpha), start should be a packed color, as from
554         * {@link #rgb(float, float, float, float)}. This is a good way to reduce allocations of temporary Colors,
555         * and is a little more efficient and clear than using {@link FloatColors#lerpFloatColors(float, float, float)} to lerp towards
556         * transparent. This won't change the intensity, protan, or tritan of the color.
557         * @see #blot(float, float) the counterpart method that makes a float color more opaque
558         * @param start the starting color as a packed float
559         * @param change how much to go from start toward transparent, as a float between 0 and 1; higher means closer to transparent
560         * @return a packed float that represents a color between start and transparent
561         */
562        public static float fade(final float start, final float change) {
563                final int s = BitConversion.floatToRawIntBits(start), opacity = s & 0xFE, other = s & 0x00FFFFFF;
564                return BitConversion.intBitsToFloat(((int) (opacity * (1f - change)) & 0xFE) << 24 | other);
565        }
566
567        /**
568         * Given a packed float RGBA color {@code mainColor} and another RGBA color that it should be made to contrast with,
569         * gets a packed float RGBA color with roughly inverted lightness (how the Oklab color space interprets it), but the
570         * same general hue and saturation unless the lightness gets too close to white or black. This won't ever produce
571         * black or other very dark colors, and also has a gap in the range it produces for lightness values between 0.5 and
572         * 0.55. That allows most of the colors this method produces to contrast well as a foreground when displayed on a
573         * background of {@code contrastingColor}, or vice versa. This will leave the lightness unchanged if the
574         * hue/saturation of the contrastingColor and those of the mainColor are already very different. This has nothing to
575         * do with the contrast channel of the tweak in ColorfulBatch; where that part of the tweak can make too-similar
576         * lightness values further apart by just a little, this makes a modification on {@code mainColor} to maximize its
577         * lightness difference from {@code contrastingColor} without losing its other qualities.
578         * @param mainColor a packed float color, as produced by {@link #rgb(float, float, float, float)}; this is the color that will be adjusted
579         * @param contrastingColor a packed float color, as produced by {@link #rgb(float, float, float, float)}; the adjusted mainColor will contrast with this
580         * @return a different RGBA packed float color, based on mainColor but with potentially very different lightness
581         */
582        public static float inverseLightness(final float mainColor, final float contrastingColor)
583        {
584                return com.github.tommyettinger.colorful.pure.oklab.ColorTools.toRGBA(
585                                com.github.tommyettinger.colorful.pure.oklab.ColorTools.inverseLightness(
586                                                com.github.tommyettinger.colorful.pure.oklab.ColorTools.fromRGBA(mainColor),
587                                                com.github.tommyettinger.colorful.pure.oklab.ColorTools.fromRGBA(contrastingColor)));
588        }
589
590        /**
591         * Given a packed float RGBA color {@code mainColor} and another RGBA color that it should be made to contrast
592         * with, gets a packed float RGBA color with lightness that should be quite different from
593         * {@code contrastingColor}'s lightness, but the same chromatic channels and opacity. This allows most of the colors
594         * this method produces to contrast well as a foreground when displayed on a background of {@code contrastingColor},
595         * or vice versa. This goes through Oklab as an intermediate step, so lightness is in terms of Oklab's L channel.
596         * <br>
597         * This is similar to {@link #inverseLightness(float, float)}, but is considerably simpler, and this method will
598         * change the lightness of mainColor when the two given colors have close lightness but distant chroma. Because it
599         * averages the original lightness of mainColor with the modified one, this tends to produce softer color changes.
600         * @param mainColor a packed RGBA float color; this is the color that will be adjusted
601         * @param contrastingColor a packed RGBA float color; the adjusted mainColor will contrast with the lightness of this
602         * @return a different packed RGBA float color, based on mainColor but typically with different lightness
603         */
604        public static float differentiateLightness(final float mainColor, final float contrastingColor)
605        {
606                final int main = BitConversion.floatToRawIntBits(com.github.tommyettinger.colorful.pure.oklab.ColorTools.fromRGBA(mainColor)),
607                                contrast = BitConversion.floatToRawIntBits(com.github.tommyettinger.colorful.pure.oklab.ColorTools.fromRGBA(contrastingColor));
608                return com.github.tommyettinger.colorful.pure.oklab.ColorTools.toRGBA(BitConversion.intBitsToFloat((main & 0xFEFFFF00) | (contrast + 128 & 0xFF) + (main & 0xFF) >>> 1));
609        }
610
611        /**
612         * Pretty simple; adds 0.5 to the given color's lightness (calculated by converting it to Oklab internally) and
613         * wraps it around if it would go above 1.0, then averages that with the original lightness. This means light colors
614         * become darker, and dark colors become lighter, with almost all results in the middle-range of possible lightness.
615         * @param mainColor a packed RGBA float color
616         * @return a different packed RGBA float color, with its lightness channel changed and limited to the correct gamut
617         */
618        public static float offsetLightness(final float mainColor) {
619                final int oklab = BitConversion.floatToRawIntBits(mainColor);
620                return com.github.tommyettinger.colorful.pure.oklab.ColorTools.toRGBA(BitConversion.intBitsToFloat((oklab & 0xFEFFFF00) | (oklab + 128 & 0xFF) + (oklab & 0xFF) >>> 1));
621        }
622
623
624        /**
625         * Makes the additive RGBA color stored in {@code color} cause less of a change when used as a tint, as if it were
626         * mixed with neutral gray. When {@code fraction} is 1.0, this returns color unchanged; when fraction is 0.0, it
627         * returns {@link Palette#GRAY}, and when it is in-between 0.0 and 1.0 it returns something between the two. This is
628         * meant for things like area of effect abilities that make smaller color changes toward their periphery.
629         * @param color a color that should have its tinting effect potentially weakened
630         * @param fraction how much of {@code color} should be kept, from 0.0 to 1.0
631         * @return an RGBA float color between gray and {@code color}
632         */
633        public static float lessenChange(final float color, float fraction) {
634                final int e = BitConversion.floatToRawIntBits(color),
635                                rs = 0x80, gs = 0x80, bs = 0x80,
636                                re = (e & 0xFF), ge = (e >>> 8) & 0xFF, be = (e >>> 16) & 0xFF, ae = e >>> 24 & 0xFE;
637                return BitConversion.intBitsToFloat(
638                                  ((int) (rs + fraction * (re - rs)) & 0xFF)
639                                | ((int) (gs + fraction * (ge - gs)) & 0xFF) << 8
640                                | ((int) (bs + fraction * (be - bs)) & 0xFF) << 16
641                                                  | ae << 24);
642        }
643
644        /**
645         * Given a packed float RGB color, this edits its red, green, blue, and alpha channels by adding the corresponding
646         * "add" parameter and then clamping. Each value is considered in the 0 to 1 range. This returns a different float
647         * value (of course, the given float can't be edited in-place). You can give a value of 0 for any "add" parameter
648         * you want to stay unchanged.
649         * @param encoded a packed float RGB color
650         * @param addR how much to add to the R channel; typically in the -1 to 1 range
651         * @param addG how much to add to the G channel; typically in the -1 to 1 range
652         * @param addB how much to add to the B channel; typically in the -1 to 1 range
653         * @param addAlpha how much to add to the alpha channel; typically in the -1 to 1 range
654         * @return a packed float RGB color with the requested edits applied to {@code encoded}
655         */
656        public static float editRGB(float encoded, float addR, float addG, float addB, float addAlpha){
657                return editRGB(encoded, addR, addG, addB, addAlpha, 1f, 1f, 1f, 1f);
658        }
659
660        /**
661         * Given a packed float RGB color, this edits its red, green, blue, and alpha channels by first multiplying each
662         * channel by the corresponding "mul" parameter and then adding the corresponding "add" parameter, before clamping.
663         * This means the red value {@code R} (which is considered in the 0 to 1 range) is multiplied by {@code mulR}, then
664         * has {@code addR} added, and then is clamped to the normal range for R (0 to 1). This returns a different float
665         * value (of course, the given float can't be edited in-place). You can give a value of 0 for any "add" parameter
666         * you want to stay unchanged, or a value of 1 for any "mul" parameter that shouldn't change.
667         * @param encoded a packed float RGB color
668         * @param addR how much to add to the R channel; typically in the -1 to 1 range
669         * @param addG how much to add to the G channel; typically in the -1 to 1 range
670         * @param addB how much to add to the B channel; typically in the -1 to 1 range
671         * @param addAlpha how much to add to the alpha channel; typically in the -1 to 1 range
672         * @param mulR how much to multiply the R channel by; should be non-negative
673         * @param mulG how much to multiply the G channel by; should be non-negative
674         * @param mulB how much to multiply the B channel by; should be non-negative
675         * @param mulAlpha how much to multiply the alpha channel by; should be non-negative
676         * @return a packed float RGB color with the requested edits applied to {@code encoded}
677         */
678        public static float editRGB(float encoded, float addR, float addG, float addB, float addAlpha,
679                                                                float mulR, float mulG, float mulB, float mulAlpha){
680                final int s = BitConversion.floatToRawIntBits(encoded), r = s & 0xFF, g = s >>> 8 & 0xFF, b = s >>> 16 & 0xFF,
681                                a = s >>> 25;
682                return BitConversion.intBitsToFloat(
683                                Math.max(0, Math.min(255, (int) (r * mulR + addR * 255.999f))) |
684                                                Math.max(0, Math.min(255, (int) (g * mulG + addG * 255.999f))) << 8 |
685                                                Math.max(0, Math.min(255, (int) (b * mulB + addB * 255.999f))) << 16 |
686                                                Math.max(0, Math.min(127, (int) (a * mulAlpha + addAlpha * 127.999f))) << 25);
687        }
688        
689        /**
690         * Makes a quasi-randomly-edited variant on the given {@code color}, allowing typically a small amount of
691         * {@code variance} (such as 0.05 to 0.25) between the given color and what this can return. The {@code seed} should
692         * be different each time this is called, and can be obtained from a random number generator to make the colors more
693         * random, or can be incremented on each call. If the seed is only incremented or decremented, then this shouldn't
694         * produce two similar colors in a row unless variance is very small. The variance affects the R, G, and B of the
695         * generated color equally, and each of those channels can go up or down by the given variance as long as the total
696         * distance isn't greater than the variance.
697         * @param color a packed float color, as produced by {@link #rgb(float, float, float, float)}
698         * @param seed a long seed that should be different on each call; should not be 0
699         * @param variance max amount of difference between the given color and the generated color; always less than 1
700         * @return a generated packed float color that should be at least somewhat different from {@code color}
701         */
702        public static float randomEdit(final float color, long seed, final float variance) {
703                final int decoded = BitConversion.floatToRawIntBits(color);
704                final float r = (decoded & 0xff) / 255f;
705                final float g = (decoded >>> 8 & 0xff) / 255f;
706                final float b = (decoded >>> 16 & 0xff) / 255f;
707                final float limit = variance * variance;
708                float dist, x, y, z;
709                for (int j = 0; j < 50; j++) {
710                        x = (((seed * 0xD1B54A32D192ED03L >>> 41) - 0x7FFFFFp-1f) * 0x1p-22f) * variance;
711                        y = (((seed * 0xABC98388FB8FAC03L >>> 41) - 0x7FFFFFp-1f) * 0x1p-22f) * variance;
712                        z = (((seed * 0x8CB92BA72F3D8DD7L >>> 41) - 0x7FFFFFp-1f) * 0x1p-22f) * variance;
713                        seed += 0x9E3779B97F4A7C15L;
714                        dist = x * x + y * y + z * z;
715                        x += r;
716                        y += g;
717                        z += b;
718                        if(dist <= limit)
719                                return BitConversion.intBitsToFloat((decoded & 0xFE000000) | ((int)(z * 255.999f) << 16 & 0xFF0000)
720                                        | ((int)(y * 255.999f) << 8 & 0xFF00) | (int)(x * 255.999f));
721                }
722                return color;
723        }
724
725        /**
726         * Produces a random packed float color that is always opaque and should be uniformly distributed.
727         * @param random a Random object (preferably a subclass of Random, like {@link com.github.tommyettinger.digital.AlternateRandom})
728         * @return a packed float color that is always opaque
729         */
730        public static float randomColor(Random random) {
731                final float r = random.nextFloat(), g = random.nextFloat(), b = random.nextFloat();
732                return BitConversion.intBitsToFloat(0xFE000000
733                                | ((int) (b * 256f) << 16 & 0xFF0000)
734                                | ((int) (g * 256f) << 8 & 0xFF00)
735                                | ((int) (r * 256f) & 0xFF));
736        }
737
738        /**
739         * Produces a random packed float color that is always opaque and should be uniformly distributed.
740         * This is only present for legacy compatibility; new code should use {@link #randomColor(Random)}.
741         * @param random a Random object (or preferably a subclass of Random, like {@link com.github.tommyettinger.digital.AlternateRandom})
742         * @return a packed float color that is always in-gamut
743         * @deprecated Use {@link #randomColor(Random)} instead.
744         */
745        @Deprecated
746        public static float randomizedColor(Random random) {
747                final float r = random.nextFloat(), g = random.nextFloat(), b = random.nextFloat();
748                return BitConversion.intBitsToFloat(0xFE000000
749                                | ((int) (b * 256f) << 16 & 0xFF0000)
750                                | ((int) (g * 256f) << 8 & 0xFF00)
751                                | ((int) (r * 256f) & 0xFF));
752        }
753
754        /**
755         * Limited-use; like {@link #randomColor(Random)} but for cases where you already have three floats (r, g, and b)
756         * distributed how you want. This can be somewhat useful if you are using a "subrandom" or "quasi-random" sequence,
757         * like the Halton, Sobol, or R3 sequences, to get 3D points and map them to colors. It can also be useful if you
758         * want to randomly generate the RGB channels yourself and track the values produced, as you would if you wanted to
759         * avoid generating too many colors with high blue, for instance.
760         * @param r red value to use; will be clamped between 0 and 1
761         * @param g green value to use; will be clamped between 0 and 1
762         * @param b blue value to use; will be clamped between 0 and 1
763         * @return a packed float color that is always opaque
764         */
765        public static float subrandomColor(float r, float g, float b) {
766                return BitConversion.intBitsToFloat(0xFE000000
767                                | ((int) Math.min(Math.max(b * 256f, 0), 255.999f) << 16 & 0xFF0000)
768                                | ((int) Math.min(Math.max(g * 256f, 0), 255.999f) << 8 & 0xFF00)
769                                | ((int) Math.min(Math.max(r * 256f, 0), 255.999f) & 0xFF));
770        }
771}
